title: The Greater Real of Archetypal Reality
summary: After the oceanic agony of Session 24, the narrative opens into a reality felt as more real than the physical, an ontological gradient where the soul moves from shadow to source. The author names this the greater real of archetypal reality: not an abstract museum of Forms nor only Jung’s psychic topography, but a living, many-tiered field that is both prior to and woven through space-time. Here, reality thickens; causality shimmers; meaning and energy are the same currency. The transition is uneasy yet unmistakable, as if stepping out of Plato’s cave into a light that reveals degrees of being rather than a binary of real and unreal. The personal life continues—an academic promotion, committees, colleagues—yet this public ascent is set against weekend ascents to a base camp of the spirit, from which further summits are attempted. The juxtaposition is deliberate: the soul’s labor is invisible to institutions, but it furnishes the energetic capital for everything that follows. Methodologically, the chapter departs from session-by-session reportage to braid segments across eleven complex sessions, preserving the major motifs while acknowledging the risk of diluting the force of whole-day ordeals. The altitude metaphor frames this: each entry begins not at the foot but from prior acclimatization; what might read as cavalier claims are, in fact, condensed from high-exertion traverses. Metaphysically, archetypal reality is introduced as a bridge-realm in the Great Chain of Being—seed reality—through which the Source articulates itself toward manifestation. Traditions are invoked not as proofs but as convergent maps: the Tao flowering into the Ten Thousand Things; dharmakaya condensing into nirmanakaya. The domain is presented as a cluster of levels, some remote and crystalline, others intimate and immanent within matter, requiring fresh categories of thought. Cleansing continues, but its grain changes: no longer trawling human history, the process now scours the subtle architecture that mediates between consciousness and cosmos. The itinerary ahead is sketched—Grinding the Bones through a Flash of “God”—with the caveat that this is a reconnaissance, not a full cartography, stepped in large strides across a terrain whose laws will only gradually reveal themselves. In the book’s larger arc, this section marks the passage from purgation to cosmology, grounding later theophanies in the newly disclosed bridge between suffering and source.
notes: Editor’s note: The author’s shift from linear narration to thematic weaving is intentional, preserving phenomenological depth while tracing structural patterns across sessions; readers should supply the experiential gravity that the condensed form can only gesture toward.
book_title: LSD and the Mind of the Universe: Diamonds from Heaven
